thread.title: Pima Football fights back from the brink
thread.title_full: Pima Football fights back from the brink

author: David Kelly
title: Pima Football fights back from the brink
text:
Pima Football fights back from the brink Posted: dkelly@tucsonnewsnow.com TUCSON, AZ (Tucson News Now) - 
The Pima Aztecs football season appeared to be sinking three weeks ago after they lost a 20-10 home affair to rival Arizona Western. 
The quarterback who had led them to a 4-0 start, Antonio Hinojosa, was out indefinitely with a concussion. 
The quarterback who had led the team to just three wins last season, Kian Homme, was showing similar struggles moving the PCC offense. 
But a move to switch wide receiver Donovan Moore under center has sparked a two-game winning streak and has Pima (6-2, 5-2) headed to 8th ranked Snow College in Ephraim, Utah on Saturday afternoon with a chance to grab a share of the program’s first Western States Football League championship. 
That loss to the Matadors on October 3rd was the team’s second straight and threatened to derail what had once looked like a promising season. 
Moore, a Tucson High product, was visibly angry on the field after the loss. He felt his and his teammates’ opportunity to be special was slipping away. 
That week prior to the club’s road game at Scottsdale, head coach Jim Monaco and his offensive staff decided to hand over the reins of their offensive to Moore. 
The 5’9 spark plug threw for 1,400 yards as a senior for the Badgers in 2013 but had played mostly wide receiver in his two seasons with the Aztecs. 
The move has paid off. Moore ran for 122 yards and two touchdowns while throwing for 108 yards to lead Pima to 45-17 victory over Scottsdale. 
He followed that by completing 8-of-12 passes for 211 yards and running for 68 yards and two more touchdowns in a rain-delayed 34-19 win over Glendale. 
The Badgers (6-1, 6-1) beat the Aztecs 72-6 last season in Tucson. Snow has won four conference championships including three straight (2006-2008). 
They are perennially among the Top 10 junior college teams in the country. 
A win for Pima would likely create a three-way tie for first place provided Eastern Arizona (6-2, 5-2) wins Saturday at New Mexico Military Institute. 
The Aztecs though would have the top-seed in the league's post-season tournament by virtue of their wins over the Badgers and Gila Monsters. 
Kickoff is at Noon Tucson time.
